ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2 hours
None
0.5 (sometimes reading the articles if there were any beforehand)
None

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths- Interdisciplinary learning experience and information on research happening in this field.Weakness- Sometimes becomes too advanced for students

I was disappointed that the seminar was SO research-intensive. There did not seem to be any speakers for those of us who were more interested in the applied side of public health. Also, the talks seemed so vector-biased. I was hoping for more humanity in the talks, as opposed to just genes and insects.
I liked the selection of speakers. It would have been nice if the different room for the CIRA talks were emphasized a bit more. And if the lunch was always on time! :-)
Interesting seminar; topics often go beyond my knowledge (for example, deeper review of microbiology of specific diseases)

Strengths: diversity of speakers appeals to a wide variety of interests by the students.Weaknesses: the length of the seminar sometimes conflicted with other courses. Also, depending on the demand of the lecture, some of the seminars appeared to not be directly focused on students, which could make them a little intimidating.
I enjoyed hearing all of the interesting lectures- pizza was a nice bonus!
Interesting speakers. Mostly on vector-borne diseases and bacteriology (less on viruses).
Interesting speakers, great seminar.
The seminar was a little heavy on the vector-born / tropical disease side of things. I would have liked to see some more applied epi speakers.
Really interesting overall. More diversity of subject matter among the speakers would be better.
The seminar series were great. It would be nice if students could be involved in picking the speakers
A lot of great talks

This seminar was a great way to find out about research in microbial disease epidemiology. It was great to be able to understand some of the findings presented during the seminar as a result of materials previously learned in some of my classes.
Great seminar, it is helpful for EMD students because they can interact with different experts in the field and even potentially find and internship.

STRENGTHS: I liked the relaxed atmosphere at the weakly seminar and the chance to have everyone together to hear the wonderful speakers. WEAKNESSES: none IMPROVEMENTS: The one change I would like to see is a couple of speakers from organizations who can share professional advice as opposed to just having speakers from the research side of EMD.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Albert Ko  Brilliant
Instructor: Albert Ko  Ko is awesome.

Instructor: Albert Ko  Dr. Ko arranged for a diverse number of seminars that covered a broad range of topics, making sure that most students could find at least a couple of lectures that could be of personal interest to them.
Instructor: Albert Ko  Dr. Ko invited great speakers- a wide variety of interesting public health talks! Great!
Instructor: Albert Ko  Probes speakers for more information making seminars more interactive.
Instructor: Albert Ko  n/a
Instructor: Albert Ko  Dr Ko was a great host and always asked interesting questions during the seminar.
Instructor: Albert Ko  Dr. Ko chose some great speakers, introduced them well, and always made sure students were given the opportunity to ask questions.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: i would recommend it because of the quality of speakers each week and great learning experience.
Disappointing - bring in some speakers to talk about applied epidemiology, or social epidemiology!
Great way to learn about EMD research topics and professors in YSPH and beyond. Pizza every week

The EMD seminar is a good opportunity to observe professionals in the field and some of the current work that they are doing, as well as some of their future goals, which can be inspiring to students who want to find their niche within the infectious disease field.
Great course- lots of interesting talks to hear and nice to see public health in action in so many different ways.
Yes, interesting.
A really good way to learn more about research going on in the field.
Yes I would recommend this course.
I would recommend this course to students with an interest in infectious disease and global health.
I would recommend this course to other students. It was a great chance to be exposed to the work going on in EMD.
